Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
City College of San Francisco (CCSF), in partnership with Year Up Bay Area, is developing TechSpot 2.0 with the goal of creating opportunities for community college students to gain hands-on work experience in the field of information technology (IT), particularly those students from backgrounds typically underrepresented in this field.

Specific objectives for TechSpot 2.0 are:
1. Recruit students typically underrepresented in the field of IT into the Fundamentals of Technical Support certificate and/or the CNIT Associate degree program.
2. Establish a computer refurbishing, recycling and technical support center to provide students with hands-on work experience that augments CCSF's existing Fundamentals of Technical Support certificate curriculum.
3. Implement innovative strategies for sustainability, including highly competitive TechSpot service fees, A+ test preparation, and A+ testing, all of which feed back into supporting the technical support center's operations.

TechSpot 2.0 builds on a proven, successful model (CompTechS at De Anza College) and utilizes a variety of networks to disseminate project findings and materials, both through in-person presentations at various conferences and through the network of the ATE-funded Mid-Pacific Information and Communication Technologies Regional Center.

To ensure that TechSpot 2.0 engages and supports historically underserved and underrepresented students as optimally as possible, the project taps into the resources of several other partners that promote equity for special populations in career and technical education programs: the Institute for Women in Trades, Technology, and Sciences; the National Alliance for Partnerships (NAPE); and California's Joint Special Populations Statewide Advisory Committee (JSPAC).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF ATE Project, “TechSpot 2.0”, established an on-campus internship program to provide technical support to the CCSF community. TechSpot is a project of and hosted by the Computer Networking and Information Technology (CNIT) Department at City College of San Francisco (CCSF). CNIT at CCSF offers courses leading to an AS Degree or Certificate in areas of information technology, including computer technical support, networking, web development and cyber security. These academic programs prepare students for entry-level jobs or career advancement in the high demand, high wage field of information technology.

 As reported by CNIT’s Industry Advisory Board and directly from the personal experiences of our students, a key element of readiness and qualification for these job opportunities is demonstrated hands-on experience with modern technology equipment and soft skills, such as problem solving, teamwork and presentation skills.

These technical and soft skills are commonly practiced through an internship at the conclusion of the academic program. CNIT students enroll in the course CNIT 197 Internship and Work Experience and earn credit for a traditional external internship. However external internships in information technology are very competitive. Students, particularly underrepresented female, African American and Latino students, have reported that they do not feel prepared and have not had a chance to apply the soft and technical skills learned in the classroom. Therefore, they are at a disadvantage without an opportunity to gain the hands-on experience that is key to being competitive for entry-level jobs or career advancement opportunities.

TechSpot envisioned a solution to this equity issue by providing an on-campus internship opportunity that allows students to gain the needed experience with real-world problems in information technology. It is led by students typically underrepresented, and students learn and experience the unique “pop-up" model we developed through TechSpot.

 The “pop-up” model, briefly, is a process that teaches students to solve and provide support for all parts of a tech support or IT problem. For a period of three to four weeks, students focus on a single technical issue. They form teams, do research, and plan solutions. Additionally the students practice, document, and present their solutions in teams for feedback. The final part of this process is that our center “pops-up” and opens its doors to help customers with that particular issue. Examples include wiping hard drives, upgrading operating systems and installing memory. We have found that at the end of this process, the students are able and prepared to solve the problem for real-life customers. The location of the pop-up can vary, for example, an empty classroom, open lab or other student area. At the end of the semester, students will be able to provide support for a full menu of technical issues and have the opportunity to practice soft skills with real-life customers.

TechSpot Website: http://techspot.ccsf.edu

CNIT Dept at CCSF: http://www.ccsf.edu/cnit
